column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Drive a Steam Locomotive
#Text=Driving a steam locomotive requires years of practice and apprenticeship , along with knowledge of the route .
#Text=For those who might sit in the engineer 's seat of a museum steam engine , and wonder what they actually did to run it , here 's what you 'd have had to do .
#Text=In fact , sometimes you can still try this for fun on an engine simulator in railroad/railway museums .
#Text=Grab the whistle cord and read on to get her moving and stopped when the trip is over , keeping the mighty beast on track .
#Text=Steps

#Text=Push the reverser/Johnson bar forward - grip the very large lever that rises from near the floor in front or beside you , squeeze the release handle and shove it all the way forward , and let go of the release handle to lock it into place .
#Text=Open the cylinder cocks - find a medium size valve in front of you on the boiler , or a thin lever on the floor in front of you .
#Text=Turn the valve all the way clockwise , or pull the lever back .
#Text=Turn the front headlight on - above you on the ceiling , there will be a large , flat , half-round box or on the side of the cab wall .
#Text=Slide the knob on the round side of the box all the way to front .
#Text=Blow the whistle
#Text=code for forward movement - there will be either a cable , cables or whistle handles , above your head or in front of you on the boiler .
#Text=Quickly pull down on the cable ( or push the lever ) twice in quick succession to make the steam whistle sound out two short blasts .
#Text=Release the engine brakes - two brass horizontal levers will be near your left hand .
#Text=The top one must be moved from right to left to release the brakes on the engine .
#Text=Open the throttle to start the engine moving - the very long lever close to your face and hanging from the cab roof is the throttle .
#Text=Grip it firmly and give it a yank towards you .
#Text=As you feel the engine move slightly , shove it back in most of the way , so that it does not gather speed too fast .
#Text=Gradually open throttle as the locomotive approaches track speed .
#Text=Observe cylinder cock exhaust and close them when only steam is emitted .
#Text=Move the Johnson bar slowly back toward vertical , but never too close to vertical .
#Text=This is like the gear shift of your car and admits less steam per cylinder stroke .
#Text=In turn , this increases the efficiency of steam usage so you do n't over work the fireman throwing coal into the fire ( and to conserve fuel and water ! )
#Text=If the locomotive 's wheels slip , close throttle most of the way immediately .

#Text=Allowing the wheels to slip will not render any tractive effort and will damage the locomotive 's driving ( powered ) wheels if done continuously ( also " tears " holes in a coal fired locomotive , or in an oil burning locomotive , can cause hollow booms much like an explosion ) .
#Text=Wheelslip , as it 's called , may cause excess damage if allowed for too long .
#Text=This includes damage to the firebox itself , which may or may not result in the locomotive exploding .
#Text=Blow the whistle at level crossings and before entering tunnels .
#Text=If you see a whistle post sign , give the whistle a long blast and start ringing the bell .
#Text=Then give another long blast .
#Text=Wait a few seconds , and give a shorter blast .
#Text=Once the train is nearly in the crossing , blow the whistle continuously until the locomotive has entered the crossing .
#Text=This is the same whistling pattern required when entering tunnels or other locations where railroad employees may be working
#Text=Do not exceed the speed limit .
#Text=That is very dangerous , as derailments due to excess speed may occur , even on straight track .
#Text=This too can cause boiler explosions .
#Text=See the Wreck of the Old 97 for example .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Visit a railway museum to try this on a simulator .
#Text=It does n't go anywhere but you 'll probably experience the sounds , you 'll get to pull the levers and you might even get vibrations depending on how far the display goes !
#Text=Try the Nevada Northern Railway for a real experience .
#Text=You can take a real driving experience of a standard-gauge , live steam locomotive for several hours on a standard-gauge mainline track .
#Text=Some preservation railways , especially in the United Kingdom , provide special supervised courses during which enthusiasts may learn how to and actually operate a live steam locomotive .
#Text=Be warned though - these are potentially expensive .
#Text=This can be quite fun .
#Text=It 's just like real life .
#Text=These are very basic instructions .
#Text=You will not be able to run a steam engine without damaging it with only this knowledge .
#Text=Search for " Engineer Experience " for museums that allow you to run a locomotive under supervision .
#Text=There are two or three in the US .
#Text=These instructions are based upon average North American steam locomotive cabs .
#Text=The cabs of steam locomotives will differ based upon builder and region , such as in the United Kingdom , the reverser might be a spool and the throttle might rotate along the firebox .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Severe injury , death and litigation may result in attempting to operate an actual steam locomotive without certification .
#Text=It is a violation of federal law to operate a locomotive without proper certification on public tracks , and probably can be considered a large theft of property , and trespassing .
#Text=Please use these instructions for your imagination , or train simulators .
